bestBHT.bht: The disciples' initial fears turned to wonder and delight as the storm suddenly ceased, and the boat, propelled by the Lord of Nature, smoothly glided through the calm waters. As they marveled at the miraculous turn of events, they were pleasantly surprised to find themselves at their intended destination. Their continuous willingness to receive Jesus was evident, and it can be inferred that He entered the boat. This miraculous arrival at the shore left them in awe, having retired from their previous anxieties.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Their first fears being now converted into wonder and delight.
As the storm was suddenly calmed, so the little bark—propelled by the secret power of the Lord of Nature...glided through the now unruffled waters.
While they were wrapt in wonder at what had happened...was found at port, to their still further surprise.
Marvin Vincent: They willingly received [ηθελον λαβειν] . Wrong. Rev., correctly, they were willing to receive; after being reassured by His voice. The imperfect denotes a continuous state of feeling, not a mere impulsive and temporary wish."

Immediately [ευθεως] . Whether Jesus actually entered the boat or not, John does not say. The more natural inference is that he did. Both Matthew and Mark say so. Their immediate and miraculous arrival at the shore was simultaneous either with their entertaining the wish to receive Him, or with His actually coming on board. Only John mentions this incident. Matthew and Mark say that the wind ceased.
They went [υπηγον] . Imperfect : were going. Literally, were going away. The verb has the sense of retiring from something. Compare ver. 67; John 7:33, on which see note; John 12:11; John 18:8.
Archibald T. Robertson: To which land they had been going.
Intransitive use of υπαγω, to lead under, to go under or away.
John Gill: When they knew who he was; and especially he was the more welcome, as they were in distress; and he able, as they well knew, to help them.
For not only the wind ceased, but another miracle was wrought; the ship was in an instant at the place whither they intended to go.

bhtAttempts.bht: Amidst their initial fears, the disciples transformed their emotions into wonder and delight as the storm suddenly calmed. The boat, powered by the secret might of the Lord of Nature, smoothly sailed through the now tranquil waters. As they marveled at this miraculous turn of events, they found themselves unexpectedly at their desired destination. Their willingness to receive Jesus was continuous, a continuous state of feeling rather than a mere fleeting desire. It is not explicitly stated whether Jesus entered the boat or not, but it can be inferred that He did based on Matthew and Mark's accounts. The disciples, in awe of the immediate and miraculous arrival at the shore, were consistently going towards their intended land. The use of the verb υπαγω conveys the sense of retiring from something. Hence, this verse showcases the disciples' journey from initial fear to subsequent wonder, as well as their recognition of Jesus' ability to help them in times of distress.

Amidst their initial fears, the disciples' astonishment grew as the storm abruptly ceased, and the boat, propelled by the Lord of Nature, smoothly glided through the calm waters. Struck with wonder, they were surprised to find themselves at their intended destination. Their continuous state of willingness to receive Jesus was evident, and although it's not explicitly mentioned, it is likely that Jesus entered the boat. This miraculous arrival at the shore left them in awe, as they consistently moved towards their desired land, retiring from their previous anxieties.

Their initial fears were transformed into wonder and delight as the storm suddenly calmed, and the boat, propelled by the Lord of Nature, smoothly glided through the tranquil waters. In awe of what had transpired, the disciples found themselves unexpectedly at their intended destination. Their continuous willingness to receive Jesus was evident, and although it is not explicitly stated if He entered the boat, it is inferred from other accounts. This miraculous arrival at the shore left them in awe, as they moved towards their desired land, retiring from their previous anxieties.

The disciples' initial fears turned to wonder and delight as the storm suddenly ceased, and the boat, propelled by the Lord of Nature, smoothly glided through the calm waters. As they marveled at the miraculous turn of events, they were pleasantly surprised to find themselves at their intended destination. Their continuous willingness to receive Jesus was evident, and it can be inferred that He entered the boat. This miraculous arrival at the shore left them in awe, having retired from their previous anxieties.

The disciples' initial fears transformed into wonder as the storm miraculously ceased, allowing the boat to sail smoothly through the tranquil waters. Their amazement deepened when they unexpectedly arrived at their intended destination. Their continual willingness to receive Jesus was evident, as they embraced His presence. Although it is not explicitly stated, it is likely that Jesus entered the boat. This extraordinary arrival at the shore left them in awe, having moved towards their desired land, freeing themselves from their previous anxieties.
